summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for previously unknown underage victims and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He possessed an address book with names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it to an undercover employee (UCE).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the individual whose former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for Epstein's underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims, connecting him to the core criminal activity.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Rodriguez attempts to sell victim address book
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempted to sell an address book containing names and numbers of potential underage victims to an Undercover Employee (UCE), instead of turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

locations: Winchester, Virginia (Location of FBI DocLab - 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez possessed an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) rather than comply with federal subpoenas to turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys.

The FBI was processing telephone records, including from the target number 323-666-9942, obtained from the address book, which were believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential victims.

This document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance to scan, automate, and format these telephone records for incorporation into the Bureau's Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.
